The Kraal is a Zulu unique building that replaces the Stable. It increases the [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture of every [ICON_RES_COW] Cow, [ICON_RES_SHEEP] Sheep, and [ICON_RES_HORSE] Horse tile worked by this city, unlike the Stable it replaces. Available upon the discover of Animal Husbandry, but does not increase the rate at which mounted units are trained. Generates a source of [ICON_RES_COW] Cows or [ICON_RES_SHEEP] Sheep near the City, if possible.

Kraal (also spelled craal or kraul) is an enclosure for cattle or other livestock, located within an African settlement or village surrounded by a fence of thorn-bush branches, a palisade, mud wall, or other fencing, roughly circular in form. European South Africans and historians commonly referred to the entire settlement as a kraal, but the word actually refers to the animal pen area within a homestead.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Zulu man loves his cattle more than anything else. He will spend hours just watching the herd - knowing every individual in it. Cattle mean status, wealth, and power. Frequently, Zulu chiefs would be buried in their cattle kraals.

The gumboot dance (Isicathulo) is an African dance that is performed by dancers wearing wellington boots, also called gumboots. The boots were a solution to a problem of often flooded gold mines in which men otherwise stood in knee-deep water toiling at their work stations. Gumboot dancing was conceived by black miners in South Africa as an alternative to drummingâ€”which authorities restricted. Another reason for gumboot dancing was for the miners in South Africa as they worked they sang. It is also thought that the workers used the gumboots to relay messages to each other that they did not want their bosses to overhear.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Gumboot dancing started to spread outside of the gold mines and into the communities as a form of entertainment. As the dance became popular, the employers took the dancers and formed troupes to represent their company. They had the troupes perform to visitors and spread the good word about their company, but most of the performances were done in the workers own language. This allowed the dancers to express how they really felt by mocking their employers to their face and them not even knowing it. These performances lead to popularizing this style of dance to where it is performed worldwide today.
[ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness-enhancing building that yields additional [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production from minable resources. Only the Zulus may build it.

The Isicathulo is a Zulu unique construction that increases the [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness of a city. Unlike the Circus it replaces, minable resources in the city yield an additional 1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. It is available upon the discovery of Mining.
